dataset.title: Sea ice duration or the time elapse between day of advance and day of retreat within a given sea ice year for the PAL LTER region West of the Antarctic Peninsula derived from passive microwave satellite

creator.organizationName: Palmer Station, Antarctica Long-Term Ecological Research Program

intellectualRights.para: Core measurments available two years after the season. Citation acknowledgement: Data from the Palmer LTER data repository were supported by funding sources

section.title: abstract
section.para: Sea ice duration is defined as the time elapse between day of advance and day of retreat within a given sea ice year, which begins mid-February (mean minimum of summer sea ice extent for the Southern Ocean) and ends the following mid-February. See Stammerjohn et al (2008, JGR) for further details. Different satellite algorithms exist.

section.title: methods
section.para:
The original time series was extracted (bin averaged) from the MATLAB LTER grid (equal area). Data re-binned into a common grid for original comparisons. Note too that the updated/reanalyzed GSFC Bootstrap time series is currently only up to 2007, but because the 'sea ice year' goes from mid-Feb to mid-Feb, i could only calculate sea ice duration up to the 2006-07 sea ice year. (So, in actuality, the 1979-2006 time series attached here is really 1979-80 to 2006-07.)
AREA: Sea ice duration for the Palmer Basin region (defined here as the region extending from the 500 to 600 lines and from the coast (station 000) to just off the coast (station 070).
ALGORITHM: Sea ice duration is calculated from daily sea ice concentration derived from the GSFC Bootstrap SMMR-SSMI time series data provided by NSIDC.
ATTRIBUTE: Sea ice duration is defined as the time elapse between day of advance and day of retreat within a given sea ice year, which begins mid-February (mean minimum of summer sea ice extent for the Southern Ocean) and ends the following mid-February. See Stammerjohn et al (2008, JGR) for further details.
Once sea ice duration is calculated for the NSIDC grid, an areal mean is determined for the Palmer Basin region (as defined above).
The sea ice duration time series, as originally was calculated using Version 1.0 of the GSFC Bootstrap SMMR-SSMI time series data and were regridded into an equal area grid as described in Stammerjohn et al (2008, DSRII). The update provided here is based on Version 2.0 of the GSFC time series, using the original NSIDC polar stereographic grid (to better streamline the calculation). The differences in the areal means due to different gridding schemes were minimal. In contrast, the biggest, differences between the original and updated Palmer Basin sea ice duration estimates were due to the improvements made in estimating sea ice concentrations in Version 2.0 (e.g., better resolution of the ice edge using daily instead of seasonal tie points). A comparison shows that the updated estimates are slightly below the estimates provided by Version 1.0, but otherwise follow the same yearly variabililty/trend.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Sampling takes place off the Western Antarctic Peninsula. There are two key sampling grids: an approximately 200km x 900km offshore grid and an inshore Palmer Basin grid within 2miles of Palmer Station on Anvers Island.

section.title: Geographic Description
section.para: 'Palmer Basin' area: a regional average based on a 25km by 25km polar stereographic grid that overlaps the PAL LTER equal area sampling grid from inshore to 70km offshore (PAL grid stations 000-070) and 200km alongshore (PAL grid lines 500-600).

project.title: Palmer Station, Antarctica Long-Term Ecological Research Program

abstract.para:
The Palmer, Antarctica, Long-Term Ecological Research project is a member site of the Long-Term Ecological Research program, a network of sites investigating diverse biomes. A team of researchers seeks to understand the structure and function of the Western Antarctic Peninsula's marine and terrestrial ecosystems in the context of seasonal-to-interannual atmospheric and sea ice dynamics, as well as long-term climate change. The PAL measurement system (or grid) is designed to study marine and terrestrial food webs consisting principally of diatom primary producers, the dominant herbivore Antarctic krill, and the apex predator Adelie penguin. An attenuated microbial food web is also a focus. PAL studies these ecosystems annually over a regional scale grid of oceanographic stations and seasonally at Palmer Station.
Palmer Station is located on Anvers Island west of the Antarctic Peninula. The peninsula runs perpendicular to a strong climatic gradient between the cold, dry continental regime to the south, characteristic of the Antarctic interior, and the warm, moist, maritime regime to the north. North-south shifts in the gradient give rise to large environmental variability to climate change. Sea ice extent and variability affects ecosystem changes at all trophic levels. In addition to the long-term field and research activities, information management, graduate student training, education and outreach are an integral part of the program.
